name: Freeman Creek
description:
Introduction

A surprisingly scenic and accessible canyon just up the road from Seven Teacups and Peppermint Creek. This canyon makes a great weekend option when paired with Teacups or if other options in the area have higher flows. There are plenty of well-situated natural anchor options suitable for different flow levels (BYO anchor materials). The descent consists of a pleasantly vegetated low gradient stretch of pools and small falls, a steeper section of slabby granite waterfalls, and a more confined gorge-like section just before the Kern River. As described, the descent can probably be done in about 4hrs, but give yourself enough time to enjoy the scenery and features. In moderate flow you can add rappel sections and also enjoy slides and some small jumps before a big final jump.

Approach

Park a cars at the exit, less than a mile from the cattle guard (there is tape marking the trail on the road). Then drive to the cattle guard and park. From the cattle guard on the road follow the old barb wire fence down the hill and into the tributary. Before too long you will approach a 80ft high colorfully stained bedrock slab that can be easily bypassed on the drainage's true right. After only 10-15 minutes you should reach Freeman Creek.

Descent

The first 0.4 miles of the canyon is non-technical with potential slides and shallow pools. The scenery is great and the vegetation is pretty open (very minor poison oak, easily avoidable).

The technical section begins at an obvious bedrock horizonline where the canyon drops more precipitously with great views. The granite patio on the true right is a nice place to don the wetsuits (if you haven't already), hang out, and snack. A couple hanging potholes before the first rappel are nice places to cool off in hot weather.

Rappel 1: 100' from healthy pine in a grassy pothole on true left. **Approach this anchor with caution as it requires crossing the lip of the slippery waterfall and traversing a narrow but good ledge. This is easily done at low flow. Setup a belay or handline if this is the safer option. At high flows you should find another anchor or downclimb the slab on true right to bypass this rappel.** This rappel takes you into a hanging pothole about 30ft down. Optionally, in moderate flow we found the crossing of the slippery rock to be unsafe and added a rappel. This new rappel 1 is approached from higher up canyon high dcl. It is on a manzanita shrub, well rooted and set against a large granite boulder. The rappel from here will take you directly down 75' into the pothole where the tree for the 100' rappel is located. Exit and continue down to the base of the waterfall.

Rappel 2 (optional): 150' from chockstone in water-carved crack on true left. *Note: on 7/23/17 we found this anchor to be no longer present. A new anchor has been built at the edge of the pool above, using a large boulder which is in the grassy area. This can add a lot of interest if you are not pressed for time (otherwise downclimb the slab on the true left). Rappel to the top of the large fanning, slabby waterfall about 40ft. From here rappel in the main flow on your back as a controlled slide (still on rope). The last 15ft you can disconnect from the rope and slide into a shallow pool (check depth first and warn all members of your party). Almost everyone in our group ran laps on this rappel and slide. We upclimbed to retrieve this anchor after we were finished playing.

There is an optional rappel here, which in moderate flow is extremely fun, and can be climbed around easily and repeated. It presents itself as a 40 - 50 foot long S shaped series of small falls and pools. In flow there are some hydraulics here to play with. The anchor is a small tree dcr at the start of the feature. The pool here has a boulder on dcl which you can climb up practice some shallow jumps (in chest high water) before the big jump at the end of the canyon.

A strolling section follows with some pools or bypasses on bedrock benches on the true right. Quite dramatically and unexpectedly the next rappel presents itself, a waterfall plunging into a beautiful but short gorge (cover photo).

Rappel 3: 60' from 2 trees at water's edge on true right. This anchor puts you right in the watercourse (good for medium or low flows). There is a crack and potential entrapment issues if there is a lot of current. In high flow there are plenty of other anchor options here. For moderate or higher flow there is an anchor on the large cottonwood tree, which safely takes you along the edge of the fall.

Through the gorge and around the next corner you'll hear and see the Kern River.

Rappel 4: 40' from a chockstone in the flowing water just above the waterfall (a longer rope might help with the pull as it is all deep water below with no ledges). (As of 7/23/17 this chockstone may be missing). This anchor puts you right in the main flow (good for medium or low flows). Beware the awkward crack halfway down this falls (it's best to skirt high over it). At high flows find another anchor off to the side on the true right. This is a potential jump (30'?), but send a scout down first. In moderate flow this crack is an entrapment issue, and not recommended. There is a large cairn anchor on the ledge dcr. A webbing courtesy extension allows for an easy pull. This rappel will use 100 feet of rope to the water's edge, but you will need a longer section for a better pull. About 50 feet below the anchor are two platforms from which you can jump. The larger one is about 40 feet above the water, the smaller on to your right is about 33 feet.

There is a large pool at the base. As of 7/23/17 it was measured at 15 feet below the jump. It's a wonderful place to hang out on a hot day. There is a fun 5.7ish boulder problem over the water that can be completed with a jump and an interesting camp. The Kern River is a stone's throw away.

Exit

Once at the Kern River follow a narrow and loose trail on a rocky slope on its true right to the next drainage to the south. Follow excellent deer trails through open forest and scrub along the GPS track marked. Long sleeves and/or mosquito repellent are highly recommended for the forest in the warmer months. If you do it right there should be next to no bushwhacking. Allow 40-60min back to the car.

Red tape

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Rappel 2 (optional):

  • https://youtu.be/kjifPXEdoqg

Background

First documented canyoning descent by Nic Barth, Alden Anderson, Scott Merrill, Pete Bohler, Sara Gallagher, and Celia Hoffman -- May 24th, 2015 (low flow conditions: Kern River at 250 cfs) Scott Merrill provided the GPS track for the exit.
